captions.text:
What doyou have
in your hand?

Throwing down the pink slip,
just likeyou.

- The pink slip to what? TheJetta?
- Yeah.

You can't bet
your dad's car.

lt's all right.
l ain't losing.

This fool is running
a Honda two thousand. l'll win.

That way me and my dad can roll
togetherwhen he gets out ofprison.
It's all good.

Well, they're gonna throw him
right back in prison after he kills you.

Hey, visualize the win,
Jesse. l'm serious.
You got to listen to me, man.

l betyou he's got more than a hundred
grand under the hood ofthat car.

Yo! Heads up, bro.
We got problems.

- Hejust raced Tran for slips.
- Oh, shit.

comments.author: Joey Venal

comments.text:
I'm no Honda fanboy, I mean this movie is what got me into tuning cars when 
I saw it when I was 17 in 2001 (I modded a MR2 Turbo for quartermile drag 
racing because of this film), but I'd imagine a properly modded S2000 back 
in 2001 when this movie came out would be capable of blowing the doors off 
a modded Jetta. Jetta's were damn economy cars originally, the S2000 was 
like a $30,000-$40,000 sports car when this came out even if it was an NA 
4cylinder. Racing the S2000 against a guy you know has a huge bankroll for 
modding cars, would have been a fools errand if Jesse knew much about 
racing cars. And then if Jesse knew anything about Chan's violent history, 
running from him and not giving him his car was a huge mistake. Even though 
Chan is kind of the bad guy in this film, I feel for him in this scene in 
that he wins a race legitimately, and then the guy squelches on the deal 
and runs off in his Jetta which is humiliating, he goes to Jesse's closest 
friend to get him what is "his car" to rectify the situation and he gets 
his ass kicked in front of a shit ton of people. On top of all that, SWAT 
teams raid him and his business and don't even find any criminal shit on 
him. He really got dicked around by the "protagonists" in this film. I 
dunno, maybe I'm thinking deeper than the director intended.﻿

comments.author: Alessandro Manica

comments.text:
+stides40
My guess is that they took the front brake calipers off to help it get more 
wheelspin on that start.  They can hold the brakes and since the front 
brakes were deactivated it helped them spin the tires more for a more 
dramatic launch.  They usually don't do much to these movie cars to 
increase power.  That means they need to use other tricks to get them to 
smoke the tires like that.

comments.author: maxblackoo

comments.text:
@0:12 sec u see my friend the tall dark haired girl. She was actually 
dating the director of the Drew Carey show that I use to be on. (He was 
married by the way, and we were at a wrap party in Burbank, and he, and she 
got into a huge fight) Anyways,@0:15-0:20 seconds thats me in my BMW M3 
black. Notice how in editing they screwed up. They the guys passing me, and 
a second later show me, and them again. We shot this at the San Bernardino 
airport for one week, in about 115 degree weather. Which turned the shoot 
into a wet t-shirt contest, which turned into a no t-shirt contest. Some of 
which actually got on film. By the way I filmed on this for over a month 
and a half. From Downtown LA, to El Segundo, to this nasty hot airport. The 
film was actually going to be called Redline, but when I went to the 
producer's and told them that the name had been used for a car product, 
they changed the name to Fast and the Furious. On set we had water bottles 
with labels made up with "Redline" on them which I still have in my 
collection of stuff. I was also one of the stunt drivers for the scenes on 
El Segundo Blvd. It is the scene in which you see all the car's bailing 
out, and a helicopter shot from above at $100,000 dollars an hour. You may, 
or may not know this but the movie was low budget, and used a lot of 
unknown's. Hell i made more than some of the principal actors. That scene 
was done in one take, and we were being chased by real city cops. In one 
scene you see this guy come up with a pizza box. Well that was actually the 
director of the movie. LOL They saved money wherever they could. I could 
tell u so much more, but i would have to kill you. For example: The 
colorful cars everyone wanted back then with the emblems all over them. You 
ever look at the rotors on them, they look real huh? Nope! they were round 
pieces of wood, that had holes drilled in them to make them looked slotted. 
And then spray painted. Yep thats low budget. i'll never forget we had all 
walks of life on this shoot. One of them happened to be a hard hitting gang 
banger. He whipped out his laptop on El Segundo Blvd, I will never forget, 
and started showing me photo's of his weapon arsenal. This guy could have 
started a war with what he showed me. needless to say those of you against 
guns. Don't be! because guys like this will always have them, long after 
you have made them illegal for everyone else!﻿

and the money is your's! Or just shut the fuck up, and go wrap your pennies!
